channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Adventure Awaits! Senior Perl roles in Malaysia, Dubai and Malta
item.description: Clever folks know that if you’re lucky, you can earn a living and have an adventure at the same time. Enter our international client: online trading is their game, and they’re looking for Perl People with passion, drive, and an appreciation for new experiences.

item.title: Perl Programmer Opportunity - Join a Prominent Tech Publishing Powerhouse in the Philippines
item.description: Our UK-based client is a global leader in the enterprise technology publishing industry, providing audiences worldwide with stimulating perspectives and unique news on enterprise tech that matters today and tomorrow. They are currently seeking a passionate and exceptional Perl programmer based in the Philippines to join their team.

item.title: Rust Maven
item.description: The Rust Maven web site contains all the new Rust-related articles and Rust-related slides. If you are interested in Rust sign up to my newsletter!

item.title: First version of the Code Maven Static Site Generator
item.description: I've started to rewrite the code behind the Perl Maven and Code Maven sites to be a static site generator.

item.title: Starting the Site Checker project
item.description: The site checker is a new project of mine. If you have a web site, let me know what would you need to make this useful for you!

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Weekly Challenge 244
item.description: This is incredible, one-liner in Python. Simply the best. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Counting Your Heroes
item.description: Rust is very impressive, I must admit. You should check it out yourself. Highly recommended.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge #244
item.description: Clever approach to solve the task. You must checkout yourself.

item.title: The smallest hero
item.description: Scalable and Do It Yourself styled solutions. Great effort, keep it up.

item.title: Count… just a little bit smaller…
item.description: Musical background to this week solution. Very interesting, keep it up.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 244
item.description: Use of CPAN module is clever move to get a compact solution. Well done.

item.title: grep and filter everywhere!
item.description: Compact solutions in Raku and bonus in Python too. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: THE WEEKLY CHALLENGE - 244
item.description: Love the innocent comparison of Perl and Python. Well done.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 244: Group Hero
item.description: Showing off the power of Raku built-in features. Perl is not far off either. Well balanced solutions. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 244: Count Smaller
item.description: Simple and straight forward solutions both in Perl and Raku, no gimmicks. Thank you.

item.title: Smaller Heroes
item.description: In depth analysis and discussed solutions. Highly recommended.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge: Week 244
item.description: Raku one-liner, very impressive. Please keep us entertained every week.

item.title: And then a hero comes along
item.description: Bloggng style is 2 way communication and I love it. Well done.

item.title: We Can Be Heroes, Just For One Day
item.description: Thanks for reviewing CPAN module and sharing the details. Keep it up and well done.

item.title: Let me count the ways
item.description: So many variations and ideas. Plenty to keep you all busy. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: The Smaller Hero
item.description: Quality post with the most creative title every week. Keep it up great work.
Very compact and cute solutions. You must check it out. Thanks for your contributions.

item.title: Counting the Smallest Embiggens the Group Hero
item.description: Clever use of map and grep to get the desired result. Well done and thanks for sharing.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 244
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Count Smaller" and "Group Hero" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 245
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks: "Sort Language" and "Largest of Three". If you are new to the weekly challenge, why not join us and have fun every week? For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: Curated list of Perl modules
item.description: One of the many great CPAN Testers, Ron, shared the curated list of Perl modules.

item.title: An Option for Syntax Highlighting on blogs.perl.org
item.description: Fun work if you are frequent blogger on bpo.

item.title: Turn off tainting in brewed Perl
item.description: Have you played with tainting on/off? Nice discussion how Perl behaves in each scenario.

item.title: German Perl/Raku Workshop 2024
item.description: Official announcement to submit papers for GPRW 2024.

item.title: This week in PSC (125)
item.description: Bonus updates, two in a week, thank you Perl Steering Council.

item.title: This Week in PSC (124)
item.description: Please checkout the weekly update by Perl Steering Council.

item.title: #644 - Perl Sponsor?
item.description:
Hi there,

Do you or your company sponsor Perl directly or indirectly?

As we all know, The Perl and Raku Foundation, is the parent organisation responsible for the development of Perl and Raku programming languages. They are also the single point of contact for any donations, whether individual or corporate. Without a doubt they are doing great service promoting Perl and Raku programming languages. I have personally seen how they support annual conferences around the globe.

Why am I talking about it today?

I run The Weekly Challenge project primarily focus on Perl and Raku but open to all programming languages. It was started on 25th March 2019. It has been going on un-interrupted ever since, thanks to the strong 350+ members of Team PWC. We were lucky enough to have solo sponsor, Perl Careers run by Peter Sergeant since July 2019 without break. Initially we had weekly prize sponsorship but later it was changed to monthly sponsorship. The best part was, I didn't have to move a finger to find the sponsor. Pete was generous enough to come forward and continued supporting the project for such a long time.

Is it time to look for new sponsor?

Well, we are not expensive to sponsor, honestly speaking. The prize money has been 50 USD since the beginning. Although I have been looking for new sponsors for sometime but never done anything about it. It is just not my cup of tea. Because of this, I put the code move on hold for such a long time. Ideally I wanted to move the code base to pure Perl solution instead of currently Hugo which is based on Go. I also wanted to move away from GitHub pages hosted solution to a proper hosted solution that we can manage ourself. I could have requested TPRF for financial help but again I am not competent enough to make formal request. As we are growing very fast every week, it is getting out of hand to manage the contributions by the team member. GitHub takes lot longer to process the data as some of the team member complained about it too. I wish we had our own repository to manage the contributions.

Any help or suggestions are most welcome.

Last but not the least, please do remember all those affected by the recent conflicts in your daily prayer. Enjoy rest of the newsletter.
item.dc:subject: editorial
